body: @andrei-ionescu I don't think we have to rewrite the data, we could just register the parquet files we want to read with a table. I think `SparkTableUtil` may help us do that but I haven't explored that api

So... given a parquet file, let me put the steps you are proposing and correct me if I’m wrong:

1. Get schema (load the data which leads to memory consumption)
2. Create new table (need write permissions and space is taken for metadata to be added plus cleanup)
3. Read data using Iceberg data frame reader (once more memory consumption)
4. Write that to the other iceberg dataset with data frame writer

If these are the steps there are the following drawbacks:

- More memory required
- Write access to the source
- Cleanup process to remove the artificially added metadata

In the end I want to add that I already tried something similar but **failed** due to memory consumption. 

```
val schema = ParquetSchemaUtil.convert(icebergSchema)
val dataset = sparkSession.read.schema(schema).parquet(sourcePath)
val datasetWithCorrectSchema = sparkSession.sparkContext.createDataFrame(dataset.rdd, schema)
datasetWithCorrectSchema.write.format(“iceberg”).save(targetPath)
```

@rdblue Sorry, missed your question !
this PR is trying to resolve #490 

When we add new manifests by calling `appendManifests(...)` , then the `commit.manifest.min-count-to-merge` property is ignored and manifests are getting merged.
This happens because of `MergingSnapshotProducer` checks `commit.manifest.min-count-to-merge` property along with if the `cachedNewManifest` is present in list of manifests. And `cachedNewManifest` is created when new files are added and not manifest files.
Thanks for the fix, let me try it.
Seems like there are some unused imports in `TestKryoSerialization`.
@rdblue , thanks for the review and comments! All are addressed. Please help to review again.
The data will not be read. It will only be a metadata operation. We'd have to read Parquet footer to load the metrics only.
Thanks @aokolnychyi!

Rebase after merging #546.

TODO:

- Substitute dependency `kryo` with `kryo-shaded`
- Explore registering Kryo serializers in IcebergSource thus no need to add Spark conf `spark.kryo.registrator`.

@rdblue - I agree that making paths relative to manifest locations is a bit more complex. But it does provide the flexibility for table to live in different locations/files systems, which enables iceberg to support more use cases. It should be worthy from my understanding.
I'd like to have some general agreement before I update this PR. Let us know your thoughts. Thanks.
@rdblue Would you please help to review the fix at your most convenience? All comments are addressed.
I can confirm the issue is resolved if we avoid serializing `FileIO`. The main question is how to achieve that with minimum changes.

@rdsr Given two different locations of data (`hdfs://host_1/input/data/` and `hdfs://host_2/input/data/`), how would you move the `day=2019-06-01` partition from **host_1** to **host_2** applying some transformations (host_1 data is parquet format, host_2 data is iceberg format)?

As a short-term solution, we can broadcast `EncryptionManager` and `FileIO` in `IcebergSource`. Then `Reader` and `ReadTask` can store references to the broadcasted values and fetch actual ones in `createPartitionReader` while creating `TaskDataReader`. This seems to solve the scheduler delay issue.

@rdblue thoughts?
@rdblue this PR is probably no longer necessary because of #507, right?

@rdblue When you merged #57 into "rblue/iceberg" branch in 22d802aca84f27be4e95bda2030ca7f423e854fc on Mar 13th, did you add the changes to DataFiles.Builder.withPartitionPath? I have the suspicion because they were not in @aokolnychyi's 234f49ffdbae82566ef8971679576d8702571fd6 merged into master.
Thanks, @TGooch44! Great to see Python docs!
Thanks, @Fokko!
@aokolnychyi @shardulm94 @rdsr please take a look at a custom Spark Kryo registrator for Iceberg in #549.

We are planning on adding support for the new logical plans in Spark 3.0. That will include support fro common SQL statements, like `CREATE TABLE ... AS SELECT ...` as well as `REPLACE TABLE ... AS SELECT ...`. It will also include support for the new [DataFrameWriterV2](https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/sql/core/src/main/scala/org/apache/spark/sql/DataFrameWriterV2.scala) API that can be used for the same operations. The new API looks like this:

```scala
df.writeTo("db.table").append()
df.writeTo("db.table").partitionBy(hours($"ts")).create()
df.writeTo("db.table").partitionBy(hours($"ts")).createOrReplace()
```

Using a broadcast sounds good to me for now.

Can you open a PR for this?

Looks like the failure is checkstyle:

```
[ant:checkstyle] [ERROR] /home/travis/build/apache/incubator-iceberg/spark/src/test/java/org/apache/iceberg/TestKryoSerialization.java:27:8: Unused import - org.apache.avro.generic.GenericData. [UnusedImports]
[ant:checkstyle] [ERROR] /home/travis/build/apache/incubator-iceberg/spark/src/test/java/org/apache/iceberg/TestKryoSerialization.java:41: Extra separation in import group before 'java.io.File' [ImportOrder]
[ant:checkstyle] [ERROR] /home/travis/build/apache/incubator-iceberg/spark/src/test/java/org/apache/iceberg/TestKryoSerialization.java:41: Wrong order for 'java.io.File' import. [ImportOrder]
[ant:checkstyle] [ERROR] /home/travis/build/apache/incubator-iceberg/spark/src/test/java/org/apache/iceberg/TestKryoSerialization.java:47:8: Unused import - java.util.List. [UnusedImports]
```
I'm closing this since I think the typo was actually correct and I haven't heard back. Feel free to reopen if you think it still need to be fixed.

2. providing that value statically, and keeping the `lastPartitionFieldId` at the `TableMetadata` level like `lastColumnId`.
3. also tried to handle the cases where pre-existing tables will not have `partitionFieldId` in the schema. so keeping same logic of giving 1000+ as the value.
4. able to run all test cases in local.
Will open a PR today

thanks @rdblue.
realized one more thing, I believe we also need to reuse the `partitionFieldId` ?
by checking if the column already exist in the old partitionSpecs , so that it can reuse the same `partitionFieldId` ?
For that we have to maintain a `Map<String, Integer>` as `partitionFieldIdByColumnName` in the `TableMetadata` so that, when new partitionSpec is updated, it can find the existing one, and reuse . the fieldId.
Yes, we do want to reuse the fields across specs. We might want to make equality ignore the field ID for this purpose.
This fix is necessary for JitPack.io because it runs `gradle publishToMavenLocal`.

The release property was suggested elsewhere in gradle docs to switch between snapshot and release repositories, so I think it works here, too. I'm going to merge this to get it in the next candidate.

Commit ad298bb286 is available on JitPack now, so will the next RC.
@rdblue Please have another look on this. Your suggestions were implemented. Thank you.
This PR won't fix the issue when existing tables have extra `/` in their metadata paths, but it should prohibit such cases for fresh tables.
Hi @rdblue , I wonder if this is something that the iceberg community will consider?

Yeah, we (Netflix) have a prototype sink from Flink to Iceberg that we use. I think it's a great idea to add an open one; we've been meaning to clean up ours if we can to get it upstream. Would you want to add a sink in Flink or in Iceberg?

I'd like to do it in Iceberg first. When the Iceberg project graduates, I can help evaluate merging it back to Flink. What do you think?

Would you prefer to use your internal one, or develop a new one from scratch (which I can help with)? Either way, it would be great if you can share some code snippets of the prototype sink early to gather some feedback and ideas.
Thanks very much for the review and merge!

@rdblue please see, updated PR to reusing field-id .
one downside I see is, have to iterate the PartitionSpec two times, otherwise have to initialize two maps from same method.
`TableMetadata.indexSpecs` and `TableMetadata.indexPartitionFieldIdByColumnName` are the ones. Though this will happen, only at the time of creating a new TableMetadata.
Please share your thoughts.
This PR will also unblock #553 as we need to handle `SerializableConfiguration` in a special way when broadcasting.

I've updated the `BuildAvroProjection` to rename missing optional fields.
Also updated tests to have a complete round trip to data file and back.

Requesting a review @rdblue !
Spark KryoSerializer calls Twitter's `com.twitter.chill.AllScalaRegistrar` that includes serializers for many Java unmodifiable collections.

Update:  For now I've made the change to only allow additions, type widening and doc updates after discussing it with @shardulm94 .  The changes are https://github.com/rdsr/incubator-iceberg/commit/4c73bf57d443f43b72c4f1913577e2ce1efd5f46

Hi @aokolnychyi are you still working on the PR?
By the way, regarding 
> Sort orders might evolve and change over time. When this happens, existing files will not be rewritten. Query engines should follow the updated sort order during subsequent writes. As a result, files within a table or partition can be sorted differently at a given point in time.

In terms of "changing sort order", do we only support adding new sort order, while it is prohibited to change existing sort orders (especially when they are tied by some data files)?
If it is allowed to change an existing sort order, we could run into problems when visiting the old data files tied to it, right?

@waterlx I have started working on this, but then got distracted by our internal milestones. I hope to submit a PR by the end of this week.

I think it makes sense to follow the same approach as we currently follow for partition spec evolution: we can keep a list of sort orders with their ids in the metadata and files will be annotated with `sort_order_id`. That way, we can always reconstruct the correct sort order for a file.
This seems ripe for automation. Maybe update this ticket to create a script for validation of a release?
@rdsr I think having a script is a great idea!
@edgarRd, how is this one going? Is it close to being ready for review?
@arina-ielchiieva Thanks for reporting the issue. Duplicate of #557 that has been fixed.
One more ping... @rdblue please have a look on this.
@andrei-ionescu, I'm focused on getting the release out right now. I can take another look after that.
Can we use Spark's internal SerializableConfiguration to avoid the Kryo problem?
Merging this. Nice work, @rdsr! Thanks for taking care of this.
@rdblue, Hadoop conf is hidden in `FileIO`, which belongs to the `Table` API. `FileIO` can be arbitrary, so the logic to wrap/unwrap it in `IcebergSource` will be cumbersome.
Yes, I think that this is something we will want to add a special case for. If the FileIO is a Hadoop FileIO, then hijack it.
Will it be worth the complexity assuming we will have a custom Kryo registrator anyway?

I'm not confident that we will want to have a custom Kryo registrator. Requiring users to register extra classes makes it significantly harder because Iceberg doesn't work out of the box. We might just build some collection wrappers that can handle this. I think the SerializableByteBufferMap is working just fine, so maybe we can customize like that.
Applying the proxy pattern looks promising, let me try that.
@Fokko, I think this is ready to be merged, but it conflicts with the iceberg-parquet commit. Could you fix it? Thanks!

I don't think that it makes sense to keep code in one repository or another based on incubation status. I'm wondering how difficult it would be to maintain the code here vs in Flink. Does Flink have a stable connector API for plugging in sinks?
Wait, `writeReplace/readResolve` won't have any effect on Kryo. `SerializableByteBufferMap` works because Spark registers `ByteBuffer` separately.
Sure @rdblue, fixed the merge conflicts
Yes, but it also appears that Kryo handles maps by serializing the map type and the entries, then calling put to reconstruct the map. We can possibly use this to build a proxy class.

@rdblue I was looking at how `ParquetReader` chooses to assign fallback ids . I think it assigns fallback ids if at least one column does not have id. The behavior is described here `org.apache.iceberg.parquet.ParquetSchemaUtil#hasIds()`

With point 3 above, your approach is slightly different where if at least one column has an id we do not infer the table mapping.

Should we maintain the same behavior here?

Also, could we maintain an invariant where a file schema either has complete file ids or does not completely, it cannot have ids assigned to only some columns. If we agree to this then we can probably duplicate what Parquet does
@rdblue still working on this. I should have something for review by the end of the week.
Overall, this looks good.  It would be nice to have some more tests to exercise the gandiva and pandas filtering paths.  Do we have any tests for that?

Might be useful to have a discussion about this.  Currently, I have some more integration type test running internally that do some data correctness verification.  I do agree that there should be more unit tests.  I'd like to get some feedback on the best way to approach it.

Sorry for the confusion. I was not suggesting incubating/graduating as an argument, but only an arbitrary time in the future to reevaluate the situation.

I think we better do it in iceberg at least for now because 1) lt potentially can take longer time (google pubsub connector took ~a year, pulsar connector took ~1.5 y and hasn't get in yet) in Flink to reach consensus, write FLIP (Flink improvement proposal) and get it reviewed, etc, and I don't know if someone wants to drive that 2) AFAIU, Flink tends to have less connectors in its repo (but show them on Flink website) to reduce build/test time 3) iceberg itself can potentially evolve faster as an emerging tech and it can be easier to make frequent changes in itself

In a nutshell, I feel it's much easier and more efficient if we do it in iceberg, similar to iceberg-spark,  and help the community to grow.
Just curious about the status of Flink connector. Iceberg requires lots of things exposed from connector, so that Iceberg could leverage it.
Thanks for merging
This seems close, looking forward to this change!

Thanks @rdsr! Looks good.

I think that the logic should be that if any ID is assigned, we don't use fallback assignment. We have to assume that if a file has any explicit ID then it was written with IDs. I think I got the logic wrong in the Parquet fallback. We should fix that as well (though not in this PR).

Thanks @Fokko, this is a good idea.

Tests are failing because of the sanity check in `build.gradle` that requires Java 8. We will need to disable that by default, but we do want to activate it when the `release` property is set so that binaries are built with the oldest supported version of Java. There's an example of using that property to control configuration here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/build.gradle#L192
Thanks @ryanb for merging and @aokolnychyi for the insights 👍
Done
@rdblue updated the PR, could you please have a look in your convenience?
@arina-ielchiieva I am going to close this one as the issue should be fixed by #557, as @jzhuge noted. Feel free to reopen if that PR didn't solve the problem.
@melin Iceberg will have full SQL support in Spark 3.0 as noted [here](http://iceberg.incubator.apache.org/spark/).

@chenjunjiedada, sorry, I missed your comment.

I think data files should optionally inherit the snapshot id and we still want to keep a way to explicitly annotate files with snapshot ids in manifests. For example, it is safe to inherit the snapshot id while appending files but we still want to annotate different files with their respective snapshot ids while compacting manifests, for example.
I am actually thinking to rename this issue into something more generic. Let me see if we can have a common way to inherit some metadata.
cc @rdblue @aokolnychyi @fbocse @prodeezy @rominparekh
Can you give us more information about what happened here? What is the configuration of the table you're writing to? Looks like you're reading Avro files. Does this also happen with Parquet?

For context, I think the idea was to catch when fallback was needed as quickly as possible. That works for cases where the schema either has IDs for every field or has no IDs, as in our environment when I wrote the logic. But that isn't necessarily the case for all data files, so we should update the logic to be more careful.
